categoryDescription: The security of ICP is based on the elimination of central points of control. A user interacting with ICP shall not need to rely on a single party. Besides architectural aspects, such as the edge infrastructure, this also encompasses operational aspects, complementing the DAO-based governance of ICP.

elements.title: Tooling for node provider self onboarding
elements.overview: Node provider onboarding through improved tooling and a GUI. Better UX for node provider onboarding than using the command line.

elements.title: HTTP Gateways
elements.overview: The HTTP Gateway becomes a standalone component as part of the new Boundary Node architecture.

elements.title: Incident Handling under the New Boundary Node Architecture
elements.overview: To protect the core of the Internet Computer, processes must be established to configure temporary rate limits at API boundary nodes during incidents.

elements.title: Community-owned HTTP Gateways
elements.overview: As part of the new boundary-node architecture, the HTTP gateway is turned into a standalone service, which is easily deployable by anyone, including end users.

elements.title: Edge Infrastructure is Fully Decentralized
elements.description: ICP is accessible through a decentralized edge infrastructure, which is split into NNS-controlled API Boundary Nodes and HTTP Gateways. The NNS will appoint node machines to run API Boundary Nodes and anyone will be able to run HTTP Gateways, enabling a much more decentralized ICP edge infrastructure with a diverse set of service providers.

elements.title: SEV-SNP-protected API Boundary Nodes
elements.overview: Security for API boundary nodes is improved using trusted execution (AMD SEV-SNP), enabling anyone to attest that the correct software is running.

elements.title: Public API Boundary Node logs and metrics
elements.overview: Anyone can analyze the API boundary node access logs to gain insights into app usage patterns etc.

elements.title: Decentralized access logs and metrics
elements.description: This milestone establishes visibility into the Internet Computer's edge infrastructure by making aggregated API boundary node access logs publicly accessible. This provides developers with valuable insights into their dapps' usage patterns and facilitates the generation of user statistics, offering key information on traffic sources. To guarantee the integrity of these logs, the milestone focuses on leveraging trusted execution environments, specifically AMD SEV-SNP.

elements.title: Subnet rental
elements.overview: Anyone can rent subnets created with possibly different decentralization properties than mainnet, and have full control over the subnet's resources.

elements.title: Certification libraries
elements.overview: The libraries assist developers in managing certification at the appropriate level of abstraction, addressing the complexity of securely interacting with the IC.

elements.title: Off-chain observability stack for Node Providers
elements.overview: Observability solution for Node Providers to enable them to independently triage node health and take corrective action in case of problems.

elements.title: HTTP Asset Caching
elements.overview: Building on response verification v2, HTTP gateways support caching of static assets such as HTML pages, JavaScript code, and images.

elements.title: Certified queries
elements.overview: Enable certified queries by having boundary nodes send a query to multiple replicas and aggregating the signed responses. Better efficiency than fully-replicated calls, and comparable security.

elements.title: SEV-SNP-protected HTTP Gateway
elements.overview: Trusted execution (AMD SEV-SNP) enables trustless HTTP gateways, empowering users to remotely attest that the correct software image is running.

elements.title: CDN canisters on edge infrastructure
elements.overview: Read-only canisters run on the ICP edge infrastructure in a non-replicated manner, bringing read-heavy data closer to the edge, analogous to CDNs.

elements.title: Chain Name System (CNS)
elements.overview: A decentralized naming system built into the ICP that allows translating user-friendly domains into various records (e.g., A records as used in DNS or wallet addresses), while ensuring verifiability and reliability.

elements.title: Node Provider Remuneration V3
elements.overview: Improves the V2 remuneration model by considering things like different multipliers per region, nodes per data center, penalties, or remuneration based on metrics such as cycles burnt.

elements.title: Strengthened node provider checks and audits
elements.overview: Strengthening the checks of entities intending to join ICP as node providers. May also include node provider audits.

elements.title: Performance-based node provider rewards
elements.overview: Non-compliant node providers are penalized economically or excluded from future network participation. This creates a cryptoeconomic incentive to encourage honest node provider behaviour.

elements.title: Autonomous capacity management
elements.overview: Making capacity management of the ICP network more decentralized and autonomous, driven by community proposals.

elements.title: Community can run system tests
elements.overview: Enabling the community to run system tests for the ICP codebase, using Kubernetes as container orchestrator.

elements.title: Decentralized backup and recovery
elements.overview: Enabling decentralized backup and recovery of canisters. Recovered canisters are guaranteed to not have been tampered with.

elements.title: Public contributions to IC repository
elements.overview: Allowing for contributions by the public to the IC source code repository.

elements.title: Gen 3 Replica Node Hardware Specification
elements.overview: Specification of the Gen 3 hardware for the third generation of ICP nodes.

elements.title: Rewards-driven DRE
elements.overview: Rewards-driven decentralized reliability (DRE) and capacity management on ICP.
